description: Origin uncertain. Possibly from French or Middle French rouiller (“to rust, make muddy”), from Old French rouil (“mud, rust”), from Vulgar Latin *robicula, from Latin robigo (“rust, blight”)

verbs.description: roil (third-person singular simple present roils, present participle roiling, simple past and past participle roiled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a fluid, especially a liquid) To render turbid by stirring up the dregs or sediment of.
examples: to roil wine, cider, etc, in casks or bottles

entries.meaning: (transitive, of a person or group of people) To annoy; to make angry; to throw into discord.
examples: Synonyms: irritate, rile, rile up, stir up
